# Adding Custom Graphics to a PDF

**Article**

Create and add custom annotation and page graphics to your PDF document.

## Overview

You can add custom annotation and page graphics to a PDF by overriding the `draw` method for [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFAnnotation] or [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFPage]. If the graphic applies to the whole page, like a watermark, custom border, or logo, you add it to the page using [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFPage]. If the graphic is something small, such as circling or highlighting a particular element on the page, or a repeatable custom graphic, such as a heart, club, spade, or diamond, then it should be added using [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFAnnotation]. Some graphics, like lines, can work as annotations or page elements.

Drawings are static, unlike interactive annotation types like widgets. To learn more about widgets, see [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/adding-widgets-to-a-pdf-document].



### Register a Delegate for the Document

Register a [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFDocumentDelegate] to the [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFDocument] loaded in the current [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFView]. This delegate will allow you to specify a method for building PDF annotations or PDF pages. The [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFDocument] is called `document`.

```swift
document.delegate = self
pdfView?.document = document
```

### Implement a Custom Subclass

Create a custom subclass for your custom graphics, one that will include your drawing. This example shows how to add a custom line graphic to a PDF, either through a PDF annotation or a PDF page.

#### Implement a Custom Annotation Subclass

Create a custom annotation subclass for your line graphic.

```swift
class LineAnnotation: PDFAnnotation {

}
```

Implement the [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFDocumentDelegate/class(forAnnotationType:)] function in the document’s delegate. This method returns the subclass type for [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFAnnotation] for a given annotation subtype string.  In this case you return the `LineAnnotation` class for a `Line` type annotation.

```swift
func `class`(forAnnotationType annotationType: String) -> AnyClass {
    if annotationType == "Line" {
        return LineAnnotation.self
    } else {
        return PDFAnnotation.self
    }
}
```

#### Implement a Custom Page Subclass

Create a custom subclass for [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFPage] that includes your line graphic.

```swift
class LinePage: PDFPage {

}
```

Implement the [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFDocumentDelegate/classForPage()] function in the document delegate. This class returns the subclass type for [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFPage], the `LinePage` class:

```swift
func classForPage() -> AnyClass {
    return LinePage.self
}
```

### Override the Draw Method and Add Your Custom Graphic

Override the `draw` method in your subclass to draw your custom graphic, the line. Draw the original content by calling the superclass version of the `draw` method. The `draw` methods for pages and annotations are nearly identical, the only difference being the `in context` parameter for annotations and the `to context` parameter for pages:

**For annotations, use this** [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFAnnotation/draw(with:)] **method:**

```swift
override func draw(with box: PDFDisplayBox, in context: CGContext) {
    // Draw original content.
    super.draw(with: box, in: context)
}
```

**For pages, use this** [doc://com.apple.pdfkit/documentation/PDFKit/PDFPage/draw(with:)] **method:**

```swift
override func draw(with box: PDFDisplayBox, to context: CGContext) {
    // Draw original content.
    super.draw(with: box, to: context)
}
```

In the appropriate `draw` method, add your custom drawing, in this case the line. To ensure that your drawing maintains its [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/CoreGraphics/CGContext] properties and doesn’t affect other contexts in your PDF, make sure to save and restore your graphics state (before and after, respectively) you add your custom drawing code.



```swift
class LineAnnotation: PDFAnnotation {
    override func draw(with box: PDFDisplayBox, in context: CGContext) {
        // Draw original content under the new content.
        super.draw(with: box, in: context)
        
        // Draw a custom purple line.
        UIGraphicsPushContext(context)
        context.saveGState()
        
        let path = UIBezierPath()
        path.lineWidth = 10
        path.move(to: CGPoint(x: bounds.minX + startPoint.x, y: bounds.minY + startPoint.y))
        path.addLine(to: CGPoint(x: bounds.minX + endPoint.x, y: bounds.minY + endPoint.y))
        UIColor.systemPurple.setStroke()
        path.stroke()

        context.restoreGState()
        UIGraphicsPopContext()
    }
}
```

- **Custom Graphics**: Demonstrates adding a watermark to a PDF page.
- **PDF Widgets**: Demonstrates adding widgets—interactive form elements—to a PDF document.
- **PDFAnnotation**: An annotation in a PDF document.
